Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Big data Analytics Driven Adaptive Learning for STEM Education
Award.AbstractNarration:
This SBIR Phase I project will develop a big-data analytics-based adaptive online learning platform founded on the principles of adaptive learning. The online learning system will provide adaptive learning strategies with real-time learner analytics. The systems will integrate learner analytics from four dimensional aspects of learning multi-media, learning strategies, interactivity, and social interaction-- to deliver a personalized learning experience for science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) students for significant improvement in the learning outcome. The adaptive learning software technology platforms with personalized learning strategies have demonstrated high completion and satisfaction rates for online students taking post-secondary courses. In this SBIR Phase I we propose to develop a unique data driven decision support interface that will result in real-time big data analytics for both individuals and large numbers of learners. The volume, velocity, variety, and veracity (the 4 Vs of big data) will be generated by the collection of data at individual schools first, with the potential to aggregate data from district, state, and even national levels. The big-data analytics of the learner trajectories through the adaptive learning platform will uncover patterns that can improve understanding of learner behavior in education.

Big data, generated by the adaptive learning systems related to learner behavior in each learning strategy, will lead to valuable insights on efficacy of the proposed methodology and development of the product in Phase II. The learner analytics will provide the basis for intelligent feedback based on the statistical evidence. The proposed method of data driven decision process for adaptive learning is based on the real- time cross-correlation statistical analysis of the predictor variables for the an individual learner. The field trials of the proposed method will be conducted in the participating high schools. Collection of data for a group of students collected during the field trials in high schools will lead to discovery of learning patterns for the clusters of learners in each learning strategy. The proposed research will then lead to the development of an analytical model for volume, velocity, variety, and veracity of data collected at school-wide level. This data then will be used for the development of decision tree and regression analysis to find correlations (knowledge discovery) that can be used for the improvement of learning enterprise (school). The data-driven feedback to students and the group analytics for teachers will provide necessary feedback mechanism for improving competency and graduation rates for STEM education in schools and colleges.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Big-Data Driven Adaptive Learning for STEM Education

NSF SBIR 1520242: Dr. Nish Sonwalkar, PI

Big-data analytics has become a buzzword for large corporations for the management of data such as financial transactions generated at banks. According to one IBM red paper, “Big data now enables new ways of doing business by bringing advances in analytics and management of both structured and unstructured data into mainstream solutions.” Big-data analytics are transformational because of the volume, velocity, variety, and veracity of the data. 

In case of online adaptive learning, the volume refers to the amount of learner data that can be aggregated by the adaptive learning platform, the velocity refers to the processing of the click stream data from the ensemble of learners, the variety refers to the different ways learners respond to the learning strategies and content elements presented, and finally the veracity refers to the validation of the response by diagnostics assessments inbuilt in the adaptive learning systems.  

EdwiseTech Inc.’s adaptive learning technology delivers what STEM education needs: an infusion of technology that will personalize learning experiences to support classroom and online instruction with a powerful learner analytics engine. For the student, the technology facilitates learning anywhere, anytime via computer or mobile device, dynamically responding to individual progress and learning strategies. The personalized experience includes continuous intelligent feedback that can help undergraduate STEM students excel and reach their maximum potential to become STEM professionals. For educators and trainers, click stream data fuels reports for monitoring student progress and course efficacy. For institutions, the technology is expected to deliver cost savings in the conversion of existing online courses for adaptive learning as well as in the creation of new courses for adaptive online delivery with the necessary learner analytics.

Big-Data Analytics (iBDADuring the NSF SBIR 1520242 Phase I grant -  ground-breaking technology development was done to create the first adaptive TM) driven adaptive learning platform to deploy adaptive learning courses with five learning strategies and analyze real-time learner behavior using multivariate five factored statistical correlation analysis which provides clear understanding on the relative importance of the predictor variable on the learning outcome.  A ‘Fundamentals of Physics’ adaptive course was designed, developed, and deployed for field trial with five distinct adaptive learning strategies – apprentice, incidental, inductive, deductive and discovery -- to the target student samples.

Field trial was conducted at 4 high school locations and 2 university locations using the developed big-data analytics engine and adaptive 2.0 platform for STEM education and the total sample size of N= 247 was analyzed for both statistical analysis and student survey results.

The multivariate statistical correlation provided big-data real time analytics for each cohort of students, providing valuable data on what worked and what did not work for each cohort. The big-data analytics engine provided wealth of information on the learner behavior for STEM course (Adaptive Physics). The most value for students in the adaptive learning experience came from the learning strategies leading to practice quizzes and also from the ability of the software to create revision trajectory through differentiated instruction design (five learning strategies). Immediate feedback that enabled students to improve their performance was a very important and useful feature that added value to the overall adaptive learning experience and higher learning outcome. It was important for students to receive revision content in their preferred learning strategy, indicating that the learning strategies were effective for learning difficult concepts. The user interface developed for the students was successful as most of the students found the Adaptive Physics program enjoyable.

The conclusions from the efficacy study are currently used to improve the design of the Big-data Adaptive STEM education platform. The field trials are leading to traction in the commercialization of the product over a large number of school systems, community colleges and universities.

The big-data analytics driven adaptive learning once deployed at large number of school systems across the USA will lead to the transformation of STEM education across the USA. The commercial potential of this approach comes from the use of Software as a Service (SaaS) model for large scale adoption of adaptive courseware deployed over Adaptive 2.0 software platform. SaaS delivery of the adaptive courseware will provide easy access to school systems across USA to take advantage of data-driven adaptive learning platform.

The big-data analytics assessment and learning outcome reports will be purchased by the teachers, school, districts and state authorities for the improvement of the educational enterprise.  The individual and group assessment and outcome reports generated will be accessed based on monthly subscriptions. While the adaptive 2.0 platform will provide necessary resource to enhance the class-room and online learning and education, the data collected will become a valuable asset that will be effectively used by the parents, teachers and administrators to bring systemic improvements in STEM education.
